facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 219 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 219 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 5, 1954 of the Allahabad High Court, in First Appeal from Order No. 353 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 5, 1954 of the Allahabad High Court, in First Appeal from Order No. 353 of 1953.

facts.text: The appellant and respondents 1 and 2 are brothers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondents 1 and 2 are brothers.

facts.text: On August 17, 1948, the appellant and respondents 1 and 2 and their mother by a registered deed of agreement referred their dispute regarding the partition of two houses in the city of Banaras to two arbitrators, respondents 3 and 4.

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1948, the appellant and respondents 1 and 2 and their mother by a registered deed of agreement referred their dispute regarding the partition of two houses in the city of Banaras to two arbitrators, respondents 3 and 4.

facts.text: Within 10 days of the reference, the said arbitrators gave notice to the parties and began to take evidence i.e., they entered on the reference.

anchor.surface_text: Within 10 days of the reference, the said arbitrators gave notice to the parties and began to take evidence i.e., they entered on the reference.

facts.text: On July 25, 1949, Rajwanti, the mother of the appellant and respondents 1 and 2 died, and the arbitrators did not proceed with the inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: On July 25, 1949, Rajwanti, the mother of the appellant and respondents 1 and 2 died, and the arbitrators did not proceed with the inquiry.

facts.text: On August 31, 1950, i.e., more than one year after the death of Rajwanti, the appellant gave a notice to the arbitrators requesting them to proceed with the reference and give the award at an early date.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1950, i.e., more than one year after the death of Rajwanti, the appellant gave a notice to the arbitrators requesting them to proceed with the reference and give the award at an early date.

facts.text: On October 1, 1950, i.e., within 4 months from the date of the notice, the arbitrators made an award and it was duly registered.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1950, i.e., within 4 months from the date of the notice, the arbitrators made an award and it was duly registered.

facts.text: On January 23, 1951, the appellant filed an application under ss. 14(2) and 17 of the Act in the Court of the Civil Judge, Banaras, praying that the said award be filed and be made a rule of the court.

anchor.surface_text: On January 23, 1951, the appellant filed an application under ss. 14(2) and 17 of the Act in the Court of the Civil Judge, Banaras, praying that the said award be filed and be made a rule of the court.

facts.text: The said application was registered as a suit the appellant was placed in the position of plaintiff and the respondents in that of defendants.

anchor.surface_text: The said application was registered as a suit the appellant was placed in the position of plaintiff and the respondents in that of defendants.

facts.text: The respondents raised various objections to the said application one of the objections... was that the award was not given within the time fixed by law.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents raised various objections to the said application one of the objections, with which only we are concerned was that the, award was not given within the time fixed by law.

facts.text: The learned Civil Judge rejected the objections and made a decree in terms of the award.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge rejected the objections and made a decree in terms of the award.

facts.text: On appeal, the High Court came to the conclusion that the award was made after the expiry of the period of limitation, and on that finding set aside the decree of the learned Civil Judge and dismissed the suit with costs.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court came to the conclusion that the award was made after the expiry of the period of limitation, and on that finding set aside the decree of the learned Civil Judge and dismissed- the suit with costs.

facts.text: The judgments of the Court were delivered by SUBBA RAO, J. on 1961 May 4.

anchor.surface_text: K. Kapur and Ganpat Rai, for the appellants N. Goyal, for respondents Nos. 1-2. 1961. May 4. The Judgments of the Court were delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.

facts.text: The award made by them on October 3, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the notice to act was given by the appellant to the arbitrators on August 31, 1950, the award made by them on October 3, 1950, was within the time prescribed.

facts.text: The arbitrators did enter on the reference by the end of August, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the arbitrators did enter on the reference by the end of August, 1948, and therefore the award made on October 3, 1950 was made beyond the period of four months of the arbitrators entering on the reference

facts.text: Learned counsel for the appellant contends that... the notice to act was given by the appellant to the arbitrators on August 31, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant contends that r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Act provides for alternative periods within which arbitrators have to make their award, that under the second alternative an award could be made within 4 months from the date of notice issued by a party calling upon the arbitrators to act, and that, as in the present case the notice to act was given by the appellant to the arbitrators on August 31, 1950

facts.text: The notice was given long after the expiry of four months from the date when the arbitrators entered on the reference.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the notice was given long after the expiry of four months from the date when the arbitrators entered on the reference and, therefore, they could no longer act pursuant to the notice calling upon them to act.

facts.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

facts.text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-I agree with the order proposed, but for different reasons.

anchor.surface_text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-I agree with the order proposed, but for different reasons, which I now state.

facts.text: The award made on October 3, 1950 was made beyond the period of four months of the arbitrators entering on the reference, and was therefore made when the arbitrators had no jurisdiction to make it.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore the award made on October 3, 1950 was made beyond the period of four months of the arbitrators entering on the reference,, and was therefore made when the arbitrators had no juris- diction to make it.

On January 23, 1951, the appellant filed an application under ss. 14(2) and 17 of the Act in the Court of the Civil Judge, Banaras, praying that the said award be filed and be made a rule of the court.

anchor.surface_text: SUBBA RAO, J.--This appeal by certificate raises a question of construction of r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Arbitration Act, 1940 (10 of 1940) hereinafter referred to as the Act .

concepts.unlisted_description: Time limit for arbitrators to make award: within 4 months after entering on reference or notice to act, or extended time

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act reads An arbitration agreement, unless a different intention is expressed therein, shall be deemed to include the provisions set out in First Schedule in so far as they are appli- cable to the reference.

concepts.interpretation: Makes provisions of First Schedule terms of the arbitration agreement unless different intention expressed.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: of words in the two alternative clauses and different starting points for companyputing the period of four months The word act is certainly more comp

concepts.unlisted_description: Deems First Schedule provisions part of arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 of the First Schedule to the Act is as follows The arbitrators shall make their, award within four months after entering on the re- ference or after having been called upon to act by notice in writing from any party to the arbitration agreement or within such extended time as the Court may allow.

concepts.unlisted_description: Time limit for arbitrators to make award: within 4 months after entering on reference or notice to act, or extended time

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 says The Court may, if it thinks fit, whether the time for making the award has expired or not and whether the award has been made or not, enlarge from time to time, the time for making the award.

concepts.interpretation: Court may extend time for award even after expiry or after award made factually; without extension, award invalid.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: of the parties gives a numberice to act, it gives the arbitrators 4 months from that date to act and if before the expiry of the 4 months from that da

concepts.unlisted_description: Power of court to enlarge time for making award

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant contends that r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Act provides for alternative periods within which arbitrators have to make their award...

concepts.interpretation: Rule imposes mandatory time limits; second alternative (notice to act) invocable only if notice given before or within 4 months after entering on reference; notice after 4 months cannot revive authority; legal position: (a) notice before/after entering ok if within time; (b) if before entering, time from entering; (c) if within 4 months after entering, time from notice; (d) after that functus officio unless extended u/s 28.

concepts.interpretation: Arbitrators lose authority (become functus officio) after expiry of 4 months unless time extended by court.

anchor.surface_text: within four months after entering on the re- ference or after having been called upon to act by notice in writing from any party

concepts.interpretation: Distinct from 'called upon to act'; narrower act of starting evidence taking; triggers 4-month period unless notice alternative applies within time.

concepts.interpretation: Wider than entering on reference; includes acts like appointing umpire; notice effective only if given before entering or within 4 months after; cannot revive after expiry.

issues.text: question of construction of r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Arbitration Act, 1940

anchor.surface_text: SUBBA RAO, J.--This appeal by certificate raises a question of construction of r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Arbitration Act, 1940 (10 of 1940) hereinafter referred to as the Act .

issues.text: whether the award was not given within the time fixed by law

anchor.surface_text: The respondents raised various objections to the said application one of the objections, with which only we are concerned was that the, award was not given within the time fixed by law.

issues.text: whether under the second alternative an award could be made within 4 months from the date of notice issued by a party calling upon the arbitrators to act

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant contends that r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Act provides for alternative periods within which arbitrators have to make their award...

issues.text: whether the words entering on the reference in the first clause of the rule and the words to act in the second clause thereof are synonymous

anchor.surface_text: The first construction suggested by learned counsel for respondents is that the words entering on the reference in the first clause of the rule and the words to act in the second clause thereof are synonymous and they mean the same thing.

issues.text: whether, if the notice to act was given subsequent to the arbitrators entering on the reference, the period should be computed from the former date or from the latter date

anchor.surface_text: In neither of the two cases the question that now falls to be considered had directly arisen, namely, whether, if the notice to act was given subsequent to the arbitrators entering on the reference, the period should be computed from the former date or from the latter date.

issues.text: whether after the expiry of the said 4 months the arbitrators become functus officio, unless the period is extended by court under s. 28 of the act

anchor.surface_text: in that event, after the expiry of the said 4 months the arbitrators become functus officio, unless the period is extended by court under s. 28 of the act

issues.text: whether the notice to act, served after the period of four months had expired, is a good notice or not
whether the arbitrators are competent to act in expectation of getting the time extended by the Court or not after expiry
as to when arbitrators can be said to enter on the reference or what is meant by their being called upon to act by notice under r. 3 of the First Schedule

arguments.claim: Rule 3 provides for alternative periods; award valid under second alternative as within 4 months from notice to act on August 31, 1950

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant contends that r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Act provides for alternative periods within which arbitrators have to make their award, that under the second alternative an award could be made within 4 months from the date of notice issued by a party calling upon the arbitrators to act, and that, as in the present case the notice to act was given by the appellant to the arbitrators on August 31, 1950, the award made by them on October 3, 1950, was within the time prescribed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ithin time on the basis of the second alternative. In neither of the two cases the question that number falls to be companysidered had directly arisen

arguments.court_reasoning: Second alternative invocable only if notice given before or within 4 months after entering on reference; here notice long after expiry

arguments.claim: Words 'entering on the reference' and 'to act' in Rule 3 are synonymous

anchor.surface_text: The first construction suggested by learned counsel for respondents is that the words entering on the reference in the first clause of the rule and the words to act in the second clause thereof are synonymous and they mean the same thing.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e, and they are called on to act, it is an intimation to them that they are called on to do the work. I can number agre with Stirling J. that called o

arguments.court_reasoning: Would make second alternative unnecessary; 'act' wider than 'entering'; supported by precedent

arguments.claim: Arbitrator can act even after four months, though award cannot be filed without court extension

anchor.surface_text: Realizing this difficulty, learned counsel for the respondents suggests that an arbitrator can act even after four months, though the award cannot be filed without getting an extension of time from the court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ould be treated as number est. In this view, the second alternative in r. 3 can be invoked only in a case where a numberice to act has been given to t

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule 3 mandatory; s28 allows extension even after factual award, but without extension no valid award; functus officio after 4 months

arguments.claim: Rule 3 imposes mandatory time limits; second alternative limited to notice before entering or within 4 months after; legal position: (a) notice anytime before/after entering but within time; (b) if before entering, from entering; (c) if within 4m after, from notice; (d) after functus unless s28

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question raised turns upon the true meaning of the provisions of r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Act... The legal position may be formulated thus (a) a notice to act may be given before or after the arbitrators entered upon the reference, (b) if notice to act is given before they entered upon the reference, the four months would be computed, from the date they entered upon the reference, (c) if a party gives notice to act within 4 months after the arbitrators entered upon the reference, the arbitrators can make an award within 4 months from the date of such notice, and (d) in that event, after the expiry of the said 4 months the arbitrators become functus officio, unless the period is extended by court under s. 28 of the act

arguments.claim: Notice after entering on reference does not restart 4-month period; runs from entering if they did

anchor.surface_text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-I agree with the order proposed, but for different reasons... The period of four months under r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Arbitration Act is to run from the date of the arbitrators entering on the reference or from the date on which they have been called upon to act by notice in writing from any party to the arbitration agreement. If the arbitrators, have entered upon the reference, the period of four months begins to run from the date they entered on the reference.

arguments.claim: Unilateral notice cannot extend time indefinitely; would defeat purpose

anchor.surface_text: The view that the fresh period of limitation will begin to start from the date of the notice if it be served within the period of four months which had begun to run from the date on which the arbitrators entered on the reference, would mean that any of the parties will be able to extend the period by just giving a notice, to the arbitrators within the original period of four months.

arguments.claim: Arbitrators entered on reference by end Aug 1948; award Oct 1950 beyond 4 months, no jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the arbitrators did enter on the reference by the end of August, 1948, and therefore the award made on October 3, 1950 was made beyond the period of four months of the arbitrators entering on the reference,, and was therefore made when the arbitrators had no juris- diction to make it.

holdings.text: Rule 3 of the First Schedule to the Arbitration Act, 1940 is couched in a mandatory form and it imposes a duty on the arbitrators to make their award within one or other of the three alternative periods mentioned therein.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act makes the period prescribed in the First Schedule for making an award a term of the arbitration agreement. Rule 3 of the First Schedule to the Act is couched in a mandatory form and it imposes a duty on the arbitrators to make their award within one or other of the three alternative periods mentioned therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 3 incorporates First Schedule into agreement; language mandatory imposing duty with alternatives.

holdings.text: The words 'entering on the reference' in the first clause of Rule 3 and the words 'to act' in the second clause are not synonymous; 'to act' is wider in import.

anchor.surface_text: This would make the second alternative unnecessary in many cases, for if the words 'to act' means to enter on the reference there is no need for fixing two separate periods for, on that construction, notice would always precede the act of entering on the reference and, therefore, the first alternative would serve the purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synonymity would render second clause redundant; precedents distinguish terms, 'act' includes appointing umpire etc.

holdings.text: The legal position under Rule 3 is: (a) notice to act may be given before or after entering on reference; (b) if before, time from entering; (c) if within 4 months after entering, time from notice; (d) after expiry, functus officio unless extended under s.28.

anchor.surface_text: The legal position may be formulated thus (a) a notice to act may be given before or after the arbitrators entered upon the reference, (b) if notice to act is given before they entered upon the reference, the four months would be computed, from the date they entered upon the reference,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive construction to prevent indefinite extensions via notices; limitation to notices within initial 4 months; harmonious with s.28 extension power; avoids stale references.

holdings.text: In the present case, the notice was given long after the expiry of four months from the date when the arbitrators entered on the reference and, therefore, they could no longer act pursuant to the notice calling upon them to act.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the notice was given long after the expiry of four months from the date when the arbitrators entered on the reference and, therefore, they could no longer act pursuant to the notice calling upon them to act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrators entered on reference in 1948; notice 1950 post-expiry; cannot invoke second alternative.

holdings.text: If the arbitrators have entered upon the reference, the period of four months begins to run from the date they entered on the reference. Any notice subsequently given to them calling upon them to act will not make the period of four months start afresh from the date of the service of the notice.

anchor.surface_text: If the arbitrators, have entered upon the reference, the period of four months begins to run from the date they entered on the reference. Any notice subsequently given to them calling upon them to act will not make the period of four months start afresh from the date of the service of the notice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of alternatives; unilateral notices cannot extend unilaterally; policy against indefinite delay.

holdings.text: In the present case, the arbitrators did enter on the reference by the end of August, 1948, and therefore the award made on October 3, 1950 was made beyond the period of four months of the arbitrators entering on the reference, and was therefore made when the arbitrators had no jurisdiction to make it.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the arbitrators did enter on the reference by the end of August, 1948, and therefore the award made on October 3, 1950 was made beyond the period of four months of the arbitrators entering on the reference,, and was therefore made when the arbitrators had no juris-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show entry in 1948; award 1950 exceeds time without extension.

holdings.text: Arbitrators are competent to act after expiry of four months in expectation that the period for making the award would be extended by the Court under s.28.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.28 contemplates proceedings continuing post-expiry awaiting extension; power not withdrawn till extended.

anchor.surface_text: The distinction between the said two sets of words has been brought out with clarity in Baring Gould Sharpington Combined Pick and Shovel Syndicate 1 . There, on January 11, 1898, one of the parties served on the arbitrators a numberice in writing addressed to both the arbitrators requiring them to appoint an umpire on February 15, 1898, the arbitrators appointed an umpire the arbitrators did number make any award but on April 30, 1898, the umpire made his award it was companytended that by the numberice requiring the arbitrators to appoint an umpire, they had number been called on to act within the meaning of Schedule 1  c , to the Arbitration Act, 1889, and companysequently the three months within which the arbitrators were required by that clause to make their award had number expired, and the jurisdiction of the umpire had number arisen and his award was ,invalid.

precedents.case_name: Baring Gould Sharpington Combined Pick and Shovel Syndicate
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between 'entering on the reference' and 'called on to act'; the latter is wider and includes acts like appointing an umpire
precedents.cited_holding: called on to act means called on to do an act as arbitrators; not synonymous with entering on the reference

anchor.surface_text: The Allahabad High Court, in Sardar Mal Hardat Rai v. Sheo Bakhsh Rai Sri Narain 1 , had to companysider the scope of r. 3 of the First Schedule to the Act in a different companytext. There, on January 14, 1919, a dispute had been referred to arbitrators the award was made on August 23, 1919 it was companytended that the award had number been made within three months after the arbitrators entered on the reference, number was it made Within three months after having been called upon to act by numberice in writing by one of the parties to the submission. Piggott and Walsh, JJ., held that the two clauses were alternative in the sense that when numberreference was entered upon at all then the time ran from the numberice calling upon the arbitrators to act., and that if they had entered on the reference, they had three months from that moment for making their award.

precedents.case_name: Sardar Mal Hardat Rai v. Sheo Bakhsh Rai Sri Narain
precedents.cited_proposition: The two clauses in r. 3 are alternative; if arbitrators entered on the reference, time runs from that date even if notice was given earlier
precedents.cited_holding: the award was within time on the basis of the first alternative since made within time from entering on reference

anchor.surface_text: This is what must have been in the mind of Lindley, M. R., in BaringGoulds Case 1  when he said The arbitrators have three months within which to make their award, and the umpire has another month after the expiration of those three months. Every one agrees, although the enactment does number expressly say so, that the time from which the three months are to be reckoned is the first of the two periods mentioned, and number the last. If it were the last, the proceedings might be very unreasonably postponed.

precedents.cited_proposition: Time reckoned from first period (entering on reference) not last (notice), to avoid unreasonable postponement
precedents.cited_holding: the time from which the three months are to be reckoned is the first of the two periods mentioned, and number the last. If it were the last, the proceedings might be very unreasonably postponed

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act makes the period prescribed in the First Schedule for making an award a term of the arbitration agreement.
